Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed compostion; back with modelled clypeus and head, prothorax and elytra indicated by single lines, and small triangles marking winglets on either side behind the prothorax line; at side, probably modelled legs (not seen); underside decorated with a winged human-headed sphinx, walking to right, bearing a short trapezoidal beard; motif possibly stamped rather than incised; pierced lenghtwise; surface worn and rough, some traces of yellow-brown glaze (but said to be unbaked and unglazed on the EEF distribution list).
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Scarabs with a winged sphinx motif depicted on the base belong to a standard group produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie illustrated a number of different versions and Southern Russia (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 28-30). This type was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-107, type XXVIII A, subtype A91-107, see especially A93 for this piece). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 30) (same type)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 97, type XXVIII A93)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.022) (phase 3)
Condition: Rather fair, though surface very abraded
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4885 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
